section.title: The Laws of Sines and Cosines

introduction.p: Although right triangles allow us to solve many applications, it is more common to find scenarios where the triangle we are interested in does not have a right angle.

Two radar stations located 20 miles apart both detect a UFO located between them. The angle of elevation measured by the first station is 15 degrees. The angle of elevation measured by the second station is 35 degrees. What is the altitude of the UFO?

We see that the triangle formed by the UFO and the two stations is not a right triangle. Of course, in any triangle we could draw a perpendicular line from one vertex to the opposite side, forming two right triangles, but it would be nice to have methods for working directly with non-right triangles. In this section, we will expand upon right triangle trigonometry and adapt it to non-right triangles.

subsection.title: Standard Triangle Labeling
subsection.p: Before we begin solving non-right triangles, we must first decide on a standard way to label them. Below is a picture showing the standard triangle labeling that we will use in this section. The same letter pair gets assigned for each angle and its opposite side. Capital letters are used for angles, and lower case letters are used for the corresponding sides. It is crucial to use this convention when applying the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines.

subsection.title: Law of Sines
subsection.p: We are going to now derive what is known as the Law of Sines. The Law of Sines establishes a relationship between pairs of angles and sides in triangles that are not necessarily right triangles. Given an arbitrary non-right triangle labeled in the standard way, we can draw a perpendicular line from one of the vertices to its opposite side, which we temporarily label h, to create two right triangles. We will use h to find a relationship between a, A, b, and B.
Using right triangle relationships, we have \sin(A)=\frac{h}{b} \hspace{.25in} \text{and} \hspace{.25in} \sin(B)=\frac{h}{a}.

This is called the ambiguous caseambiguous case and can arise when we know two sides and a non-included angle. In the ambiguous case we may find that a particular set of given information can lead to 2 solutions, 1 solution, or no solution at all. However, when an accurate picture of the triangle or suitable context is available, we can determine which angle is desired.

statement.p: Given A=80^\circ, a=120, and b=121, find the corresponding and missing sides and angles. If there is more than one possible solution, show both.

solution.p:
Let us start by drawing a picture with the given information.
triangle Using the Law of Sines, we get the equation \dfrac{\sin(80^\circ)}{120}=\dfrac{\sin(B)}{121} To solve for B, we can multiply both sides of the equation by 121 to get that 121\cdot\dfrac{\sin(80^\circ)}{120}=\sin(B) We can now use the inverse sine function to solve for B. Using our calculator, we get that B=\sin^{-1}\left(121\cdot\dfrac{\sin(80^\circ)}{120}\right)\approx83.224^\circ To solve for the other possible solution, we can use symmetry to get that B\approx180^\circ-83.224^\circ=96.776^\circ Since both of these answers make sense, we need to consider what happens for each of them. If B\approx83.224^\circ, then C\approx180^\circ-80^\circ-83.224^\circ\approx16.776^\circ. Now that we know C, we can again use the Law of Sines to find c: \dfrac{\sin(80^\circ)}{120}=\dfrac{\sin(16.776^\circ)}{c} Solving for c, we get that c=\dfrac{120\sin(16.776^\circ)}{\sin(80^\circ)}\approx35.17 We have now solved for all of the unknowns for this value of B.

Now consider the case where B\approx96.776^\circ. If B\approx96.776^\circ, then C\approx180^\circ-80^\circ-96.776^\circ\approx3.224^\circ. Now that we know C, we can again use the Law of Sines to find c: \dfrac{\sin(80^\circ)}{120}=\dfrac{\sin(3.224^\circ)}{c} Solving for c, we get that c=\dfrac{120\sin(3.224^\circ)}{\sin(80^\circ)}\approx6.853 We have now solved for all of the unknowns for this value of B. All together, we get that there are two possible triangles with a, A, and b as given:

subsection.title: Law of Cosines

paragraphs.p: Suppose a boat leaves port, travels 10 miles, turns 20 degrees, and travels another 8 miles. How far from port is the boat?

Unfortunately, while the Law of Sines lets us address many non-right triangle cases, it does not allow us to address triangles where the one known angle is included between two known sides, which means it is not a corresponding angle for a known side. For this, we need another tool: the Law of Cosines.

subsection.p: Similar to the Law of Sines, the Law of Cosines establishes a relationship between the sides of a triangle and its angles. In particular, it relates all three sides and *any* of the three angles. We will derive it by again drawing adding in a perpendicular line and using what we know about right triangles.

Given an arbitrary non-right triangle, we can draw a perpendicular line from one vertex to the opposite side, which we temporarily label h, to create two right triangles. We will divide the base b into two pieces, one of which we will temporarily label x.

subsection.p: This result is called the Law of Cosines. If we draw the line perpendicular to one of the other two sides, we could establish this relationship using any angle. The important thing to note is that the right side of the equation involves an angle and the sides adjacent to that angle while the left side of the equation involves the side opposite that angle.

assemblage.title: Law of Cosines
assemblage.p: Given a triangle with angles and opposite sides labeled as shown, a^2=b^2+c^2-2bc\cos(A) b^2=a^2+c^2-2ac\cos(B) c^2=a^2+b^2-2ab\cos(C)

subsection.p: Notice that if one of the angles of the triangle is 90 degrees, then the formula c^2=a^2+b^2-2ab\cos(C) simplifies to c^2=a^2+b^2 since \cos(90^\circ)=0.

You should recognize this as the Pythagorean Theorem. Indeed, the Law of Cosines is sometimes called the Generalized Pythagorean TheoremGeneralized Pythagorean Theorem since it extends the Pythagorean Theorem to non-right triangles.
In addition to solving for the missing side opposite one known angle, the Law of Cosines allows us to find the angles of a triangle when we know all three sides.
